docs.lead_paragraph: Robert Dardinger, a retired history teacher, is both pleased and perplexed by a decision of the Ohio Supreme Court the other day. The perplexing part, he says, is that he was ordered to make a $20 million charitable donation. The court, in a 4-to-3 decision issued on Dec. 20, upheld punitive damages of $30 million against an insurance company that, it said, had expertly deployed every sort of bureaucratic intransigence to deny treatment to Mr. Dardinger's wife, Esther, who died from brain cancer in 1997 at age 49.

headline.main: Court Dictates How to Spend Award

docs.abstract: Article on Ohio Supreme Court decision upholding punitive damages of $30 million against Anthem Inc, insurance company it said schemed to deny treatment to brain cancer patient Esther Dardinger, who died in 1997; court has ordered Dardinger's husband Robert to donate $20 million to cancer research fund court ordered established at James Cancer Hospital at Ohio State University; decision raises questions about whether legislatures and courts should be allowed to divert and allocate such awards; Dardinger says he had planned to set up his own foundation for cancer research and to help people with cancer; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Police Department laid off 103 janitorial workers yesterday, the first employees to lose their jobs in a department that must trim its spending by nearly 6 percent next year as the city faces a fiscal crisis unlike any since the 1970's. The workers received letters signed by Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly yesterday informing them that their jobs were being eliminated.

headline.main: 103 Janitors For the Police Are Laid Off In First Cuts

docs.abstract: New York City Police Dept lays off 103 janitorial workers, first employees to lose their jobs as department begins trimming spending by 5.7 percent; layoffs are merely beginning of what promises to be grim belt-tightening period (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Over and over again, Catherine Dunlap has had her dreams deferred. Dreams of moves, travels, new starts. For 38 years, Mrs. Dunlap worked hard cleaning other people's houses. Together, she and her husband, Frank, dreamed of returning to live near their hometowns in South Carolina. But when he died of cancer at 57 in 1984, that wish gave way to the realities of raising two teenagers, Jeannie and Gary, by herself.

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; Dreams Deferred, Dreams Recast to Include 2 Children

docs.abstract: Catherine Dunlap struggled with mounting expenses when her grandchildren came to live with her after their mother died; Catholic Charities helps with counseling and New York Times Neediest Cases Fund money helps buy beds; photo (M)

keywords.value: NEW YORK TIMES NEEDIEST CASES FUND

docs.lead_paragraph: Prices of generic drugs are rising almost twice as rapidly as prices of brand-name drugs, even as many insurers and the Bush administration are pressing Americans to switch in the name of saving money. The trend is expected to continue over the next few years as a number of enormously popular brand-name drugs lose their patent protection and drug makers introduce generic versions at high initial prices.

headline.main: As Patents on Popular Drugs End, Costs for Generics Show a Surge

docs.abstract: Prices of generic drugs are rising almost twice as rapidly as prices of brand-name drugs, even as many insurers and Bush administration press Americans to switch in name of saving money; trend is expected to continue over next few years as some enormously popular brand-name drugs lose their patent protection and drug makers introduce generic versions at high initial prices; prices of generic drugs are rising faster because makers of generics typically charge higher prices when first generic versions of expensive medicines are offered; also, generic-drug industry is consolidating, leaving fewer companies to compete on prices of older generic drugs; wholesalers, drug plan managers and pharmacies all find they can make higher profits on generic drugs than on brand-name medicines and still offer prices that are typically well below those of brand-name drugs; trend concerns those who saw generic drugs as way to hold down medical costs for Americans without depriving them of necessary treatments; rapid price increases come on heels of Pres Bush's proposal to help generic drugs reach market faster, plan vehemently opposed by makers of brand-name drugs; photo; graph (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Mary Jane Gregory recently walked out of Discount Drugs of Canada here with a 33 percent savings on her osteoporosis drug that outweighed any doubts she might have had about the new store, which gets her prescription filled in distant Winnipeg. ''I don't know whether it's illegal or not, but it's right out here in the open,'' Ms. Gregory, 71, said. ''How bad can it be?''

headline.main: A New Source for Discount Prescriptions

docs.abstract: Small storefront operations cropping up across US take orders for discount prescription drugs from Canada; US pharmacies are unhappy but regulators are reluctant to crack down on buyers, many of whom are older people with limited incomes; Earle Turow says he is not breaking law because his Delray Beach, Fla, store just takes orders and faxes them to Canadian pharmacy that ships drugs to customers; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Mary Jane Gregory recently walked out of Discount Drugs of Canada here with a 33 percent savings on her osteoporosis drug that outweighed any doubts she might have had about the new store, which gets her prescription filled in distant Winnipeg.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Drug companies and doctors are fighting a Bush administration plan to restrict gifts and other rewards that pharmaceutical manufacturers give doctors and insurers to encourage the prescribing of particular drugs. In October, the Department of Health and Human Services said many gifts and gratuities were suspect because they looked like illegal kickbacks. Since then, a few consumer groups, including AARP, have voiced support for the restrictions. But they are outnumbered by the drug makers, doctors and health maintenance organizations that have flooded the government with letters criticizing the proposal.

headline.main: Drug Makers Battle A U.S. Plan to Curb Rewards for Doctors

docs.abstract: Drug companies and doctors fight Bush administration plan to restrict gifts and other rewards that pharmaceutical manufacturers give doctors and insurers to encourage prescribing of particular drugs; Dept of Health and Human Services says many gifts and gratuities look like illegal kickbacks, and consumer groups including AARP voice support for restrictions; they are outnumbered by drug makers, doctors and health maintenance organizations that have flooded government with letters criticizing proposal; drug makers acknowledge that they routinely make payments to insurance plans to increase use of their products, to expand their market share, to be added to lists of recommended drugs or to reward doctors and pharmacists for switching patients from one brand of drug to another; insurers, doctors and drug makers say such payments are so embedded in structure of health care industry that Bush administration plan would be profoundly disruptive; doctors say drug companies are major source of money for their professional education programs; administration says it is considering these comments and expects to issue final guidelines in few months (M)
docs.snippet: Drug companies and doctors are fighting a Bush administration plan to restrict gifts and other rewards that pharmaceutical manufacturers give doctors and insurers to encourage the prescribing of particular drugs.    In October, the Department of...

docs.lead_paragraph: A former top Nassau County official pleaded guilty in Federal District Court yesterday to receiving $150,000 in bribes as part of a health insurance scheme that the authorities said cost the county $70 million. The former official, Robert J. McDonald, 68, acknowledged that while serving as the chief deputy to Thomas S. Gulotta, then the county executive, he helped a company fraudulently win contracts to handle health benefits plans for county employees. Mr. McDonald's co-defendants are scheduled to go on trial next month, officials said. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Central Islip: Official Pleads Guilty

docs.lead_paragraph: So, little Heather Smith is a bit of a ham. There she sits, nibbling on a lollipop, with the sweet but disengaged air of a teenage princess, as she listens to her mother and camp coordinator discuss, in appropriately low tones, her problems. ''She's had nine surgeries,'' her mother, Elsie Guilarte-Smith explains. ''Her stomach was opened, her bladder opened. Her feet had to be uncurled.''

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; Nine Operations Can't Break the Spirit of a Girl, 14

docs.lead_paragraph: Yahoo to Pay $235 Million For Web Search Technology Moving to re-establish itself as a pre-eminent place to search the Internet, Yahoo plans to buy Inktomi, a maker of Web search technology, for $235 million in cash. The acquisition provides somewhat of a soft landing for Inktomi, whose shares hit $231 in March 2000 -- giving it a value of about $25 billion -- but whose expansion plans largely collapsed. Market Place. [Page C3.]

docs.lead_paragraph: Bill Frist of Tennessee was unanimously elected the Republican leader of the Senate today, urged by his colleagues to remake the reputation of a party that many felt had been seriously damaged by the comments of the man he succeeds, Senator Trent Lott. Dr. Frist, who will become majority leader next month when the 108th Congress convenes, was selected by acclamation in a conference call among 48 Republican senators and senators-elect across the country. Last month, they chose Mr. Lott as their leader in the customary Capitol Hill meeting, but on Dec. 5 Mr. Lott made a remark about retiring Senator Strom Thurmond that appeared to express nostalgia for segregation, and he stepped down on Friday amid a gathering furor.

headline.main: REPUBLICANS ELECT FRIST OF TENNESSEE AS SENATE LEADER

docs.abstract: Republican senators and senators-elect unanimously elect Sen Bill Frist as Republican leader of Senate, succeeding Sen Trent Lott, conference call; Frist will become majority leader when Congress convenes; he vows to heal 'wounds of division'; Lott, who takes part in call, reportedly expresses no recriminations and apologizes to colleagues for uproar he caused with remarks praising Sen Strom Thurmond; Pres Bush congratulates Frist; photos (M)
